title: Sony Shutting PlayStation Vue as Consolidation Starts in Skinny-Bundle Video
text:
Text size

In a sign that the market for streaming video “skinny bundles” could be headed for a period of consolidation, Sony today said it is shutting down PlayStation Vue, the company’s four-year-old subscription video service, effective Jan. 30, 2020.

“Unfortunately, the highly competitive Pay TV industry, with expensive content and network deals, has been slower to change than we expected,” Sony (ticker: SNE) said in a blog post. “Because of this, we have decided to remain focused on our core gaming business.”

Vue is one of at least a half-dozen over-the-top services offering bundles of basic cable and local broadcast channels in competition with traditional cable and satellite TV services. Other players in the crowded space include AT&T’s (T) DirecTV Now, Dish Network’s (DISH) Sling TV, Alphabet’s (GOOGL) YouTube TV, Hulu + Live TV, FuboTV, Philo, and Frndly TV.

Just a week ago, the Information reported that Sony had hired Bank of America Merrill Lynch to seek a buyer for the service, which according to that story had about 500,000 subscribers. That story had named FuboTV, a sports-oriented over-the-top service, as a potential buyer, but apparently no deal materialized.

Data from eMarketer earlier this year named Sling TV as the leader in the skinny-cable bundle market, with about 2.4 million subscribers, followed by Hulu + Live TV at 2 million, DirecTV Now with 1.5 million, YouTube TV with 1 million, PlayStation Vue with 800,000, and Fubo with 300,000.

As more premium subscription services launch— Apple’s (AAPL) Apple TV+ goes live Nov. 1 and Walt Disney’s (DIS) Disney+ starts streaming on Nov. 12—it is clearer than ever that the need for access to broadcast and basic-cable channels is limited beyond news and sports. While cord-cutting continues unabated, many cord-cutters simply aren’t choosing to sign up for a skinny bundle to take the place of traditional cable. And the steady price increases installed by most of the skinny-bundle providers has made them a lot less appealing to consumers than they once were.
